SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

1906

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: ARTHUR JAMES WHEELER
Present Address: BANK END SASK.
Pioneer Address: LADSTOCK PO SASK.
Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1906

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth?
   Million 2 miles, about 10.
   How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?
   Occasionally

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days?
   No, only when we needed company.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?
   Usually without invitation.

What time of the day did you go, in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?
   Yes, in the morning, and at another bachelor stay overnight or maybe 2-3 days.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?
   Yes, just took pot luck.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly?
   (That is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"?
   A drink of milk maybe, or a cup of strong tea.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?
   Yes.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.
   Whenever a building was being put up, or for wood saving, it was an opportunity for bachelors to get some company and a change in diet, and always they avoided them.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.
   Not many, but we did have good parties and dances at the few married people's homes suitable, also bachelors had their parties of their own; sometimes married men & wives would visit bachelors.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.
   Bachelor dancing slowly increased 1912, around 1920 to 1923. Hot old time dances at neighbors' homes were very popular.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?
   No.

Gradually declined as schools & halls were built.
PIONEER RECREATION AND SOCIAL LIFE

1. In the first five years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday or other day? Yes, we always visited on Sundays.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

What time of the day did you go? In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Yes, for our rural life, and let another.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes, we often stayed over night and may go back.

How was the invitation to dinner worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "make pollywood" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? A drink of milk or a cup of sugar tea.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there any parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe.

The not married couples would have parties, circled by the unmarried persons and the bachelors and old maids. Sometimes arranged men's dances, mixed parties, bachelor clubs, and a change in dates and a change in dates.

8. Did you socially meet each other? Yes, we did have good parties and dances.

At the first marriages parties and circled by their own.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? Yes, we did have parties and dances.

Gradually closed down, and halls were built.
On one occasion in 1907, we organized a bee, to map and cut a road through the back around Steynes in order that a settler could get into his new neighbors' land. He was Mr. Blackmore, a Yorkshireman who had been brought in by a homesteader who had recently arrived, who knew many settlers. Mr. Blackmore showed him good land and settled there. However, all the settlers on this land eventually found their way out.

As a consequence, the old chap couldn't find his way out, so he had three nice daughters. The bachelors soon came calling for them, and their family never lacked company. The bachelors turned up in force. After this, the old man started looking for someone to marry. He fell ill, but some of them went about the same time.

We helped a neighbor shingle the roof of a log building. It was divided into two rooms by a long partition; there were doors between. The family used no floors in the partition. I believe now the family used to go outdoors before they could get inside. In order to avoid this, they put ladders each side of the partition and climbed up and down when visiting. Later, when the settler finally decided to cut a door in the partition, we helped numerous other bees, such as putting on sod roofs.

There were numerous other bees, such as putting on sod roofs. There were also many throughout building log barns and houses.

Getting the work done.

Parties & Dances.

The first dance I attended was at the home of Ed Rincon. A man who had served his time on the old sailing ships eventually became a captain. On December 24th, 1906, he had a piano (the same one he Destroyed) which he played on. Also, there was a fiddle with piano provided. Everyone had a great time, and we played a game, cards were also played. The game was called Pig. We were just playing until we heard Ed say "Come downstairs." While playing our game, George and Ed sat down at the piano, and George was asleep on the floor. I believe Ed said "Come downstairs," when George's mother put up her hand. Another lady player thought it was funny and said "What's so funny?" She thought that the guest who was not laughing was Ed. However, she did not have any hopes, thinking Ed was indeed.

Ed suddenly discovered he was Pig.
Bess, on one occasion in 1909, we organized a bee.

We met at a local store, where we sold goods to the townspeople. We had a good time, and the people were very kind to us.

One day, we went to visit a friend who lived in another town. We had a wonderful time there, and we made many new friends.

On another occasion, we went to a nearby town to attend a festival. It was a very exciting event, and we enjoyed ourselves immensely.

We also attended a wedding, which was a very special occasion. The bride and groom were very happy, and we wished them well.

In conclusion, we had a wonderful year, and we look forward to many more adventures in the future.

Parties & Dances

Then on Jan 1st 1907 I attended my first bachelor party at the home of Jack McMillan to celebrate New Year's Day. Eleven bachelors all the cooking done by Jack.

About the same time we had another story party at Walter Cox's, dance & cards, winding up with a huge plum pudding.

However dances were few and far between more frequently until 1920 to 1925 when through the activities of the SGG a local many social gatherings were organized at the school and in farm homes.

Six years old time fiddlers and dancers who got to know fiddlers were Norman McMenney Tom Foster Sam Foster Alex MacKenzie Andrew Fisher & others.

Box Pic & Shadow Socials were very popular. Boxes were a work of art and were auctioned off at times being sold for $10.00 and $15.00 when two young fellows were fighting against one another. On occasion they would discover they had won just the girl they liked.

The late Alex McPhail President of the Earl Wheat Pool attended many of these gatherings.

I believe that the atmosphere of good will, neighbourliness and real pleasure of these events of bygone days can never return because they were free of liquor.

On the advent of prohibition and the introduction of home brew, the character of social events rapidly changed and to a large extent prevailed today.

As a consequence schools are rarely used for dances now, because of damage caused in the past.

Dances consist of an occasional card party alone being held.

Perhaps I should mention the Chautauquas of early years. They came to Levers in 1920 & 21 and attracted people from all over the country. The entertainment was exceptionally good. In 1922 I well remember an address given by Miss Parkhurst the British suffragette leader.
Paul's Quince

Then on Jan 18th 1907 I attended my first bachelor's party at Mr. Miller's home of Jack Miller's new year's party. We had cards, cake, punch, etc.

At the same time we had another party at Walter Cox's. Dance, cards, wine, etc.

A large group gathered in the social hall where there was a card and dance. Many social gatherings were organized.

In 1920-1921 when the school was closed due to the flu epidemic and classes were held in the gymnasium, many social activities took place.

The Pale Ale, McPhail, President of the Social Club, attended many of these gatherings.

He always tried to make sure that everyone had a good time.

As a consequence, he was very popular among his fellow students.

On occasion, he would get into trouble.

But he always managed to get out of it.

In conclusion, I should mention that the students of early years they came to favor in 1920 and 1921 and all the people from all over the country were remembered an address exceptionally well.

P.S. To Mrs. Penkhus, I am grateful for your kindness.

Chivaree.

These fairly common but I only attended one in August 8th 1922 when the neighbors gathered at my house to chivaree my brother-in-law.

Invited with some homemade wine and old bottles, bowls, pans, discs and other instruments we started out about 11 p.m. on nearing my brother's house found he was still up so waited till the light went out then made a run for it, circling the house yelling and beating our instruments the fun was terrific. Brother did not show up for a while but said the noise was too much and the door opened when we all trooped in Cap. Ruvolon carrying a cream can on which were a number of shiny red herrings. Cap says "Sit up Frank it is chilly" but that cap opens the oven door and pops the herrings in after a while he opened the door to get more heat as he said but came a cloud of smoke. Frank's wife says "That is that awful smell" oh says cap we brought our supper along" but they herrings were soon eaten outside where they were placed under the seat and in the engine block of an old car belonging to me of the party who on going home could smell the herrings but did not find them for some time a good lunch ended my one and only chivaree.

Sask Grain Growers Association Allenby Local.

The steps leading to its organization were brought about by the late Alex McPhail who at that time was actively working in the interest of agricultural life and its improvement. It was in this area that he commenced his activities his objective being the uplift of Sask. Farm population in which he was so successful when he eventually became President of the Sask. Wheat Pool.

Milo Rockwell was the first president of the local.

Harry Beantard Sec. known.

At the first meeting Alex McPhail gave an address.

The local organized picnics which were very popular and eagerly attended. It also was interested in the formation of the Wheat Pool. At an annual meeting Jan. 15 1921 (from the minutes) moved by A.J. Wheeler that our delegates to the S.G.G.A convention at Moose Jaw Feb. 1st be instructed to vote in favor of a Wheat Pool.

Policies also entered into the deliberations

From the minutes Jan 15 1921

moved by E.H. Palucki

The Local does not consider the time ripe for the Association to enter Provincial Policies.
We had a great time at the fair last night. It was so much fun to see all the different rides and games. The food was delicious too! We tried the cotton candy and it was so sweet. Overall, it was a fantastic experience.

The weather was perfect and the sun was shining brightly. We spent most of our time playing games and eating snacks. It was a bit crowded, but we managed to find a few spots to sit and relax.

We also got to meet some new people who were there with their families. It was nice to see everyone enjoying themselves. The music was really good too, and we danced the night away.

Overall, it was a wonderful day and we can't wait to go back next year!

A team was the first club organized in this area against Franklin Heights and a sketcher. Other teams were Raymore and Jackson Falls had a team. Games were held at the Miners' Club & Holden.

Played in a league. Miners' Club & Holden. Not sure if they played for any other teams. Also played at the Miners' Club & Holden. Then moved to Franklin. Taken from fall played at their grounds. Fall day.

The teams were composed mostly of old cricket players. Dave Cuthbert, goal keeper. Best Scott & Mr. Palmer. Enclosed.

Campbell, Mechanicsville.
Soccer was the first sport organized in this area. A team was organized at Town Lake who played against Yopp's Hopyard & Fletcher. Other teams were Raymine and I believe Macdonald Falls had a team also. Tile Hills & Indian Reserve. I know Town Lake, Hopyard, Town Lake & Fletcher played in a league. I am not sure if they had a team.

My partner Mr. Cole & St. Patrick played full back for Town Lake often driving 25 miles into town & buying to play. On June 23rd, 1911 we drove to Town Lake then took train to Hopyard when Town Lake played Hopyard at their Coronation Sports day.

On July 13th, 1912 I went to Town Lake and saw them beat Yopp's 8-1.

The teams were composed mostly of old country players. Some of Town Lake's team were Dave Butten, goal keeper of Ladolote, a Scot, Bert Abbott & St. Patrick. Englishmen Charlie Fitzsimmons, Dunlop, Campbell, McKean & others.

40. An old time Henry George Salvator Band End.

Recalled to me that he drove cattle in 4 directions from South Dubuque (13 days or road) via Telegraph Shore to Dubuque sports day May 24th 1897. This was a short day for the Indians so many as 500 tipped on the ground.

He also attended a big celebration at 4th of July in June 30th 1897 in honor of Queen Victoria's Diamond Jubilee.

Probably the first sports day held on two acre grounds at Kalamazoo in 1897 because it was here that there was a trading post also the Hudson Bay Post at Stockwell. In 1907 a purchase grade 20-10-10 started by Mr. George Salvator Sr. since then building classes etc.
